Fact.Name: Income-state options
Fact.Description: Whether the filer earned income in a state from the allowed scopedStateOptions

Fact.Name: Income-state options
Fact.Description: Whether the filer earned income in a state from the allowed scopedStateOptions

Fact.Name: Options for whether the filers spouse lived in the same state with them
Fact.Description: Options to describe whether the filer's spouse lived in the same state as the filer all year
The tax day for the primary filer, taking their contact address into account

Fact.Name: Filers
Fact.Description: The filers of the tax return. If a joint return, there are two filers; otherwise, there is only one.

Fact.Name: First name
Fact.Description: The first name of the filer. Must match the name as known to the Social Security Administration.

Fact.Name: Middle initial
Fact.Description: The middle initial of the filer. Must match the name as known to the Social Security Administration. This is the writable optional fact. Can be left incomplete. Please use the derived fact in downstream calculations.

Fact.Name: Middle Initial
Fact.Description: The middle initial of the filer. Must match the name as known to the Social Security Administration.

Fact.Name: First name and initial
Fact.Description: The first name and middle initial of the filer.

Fact.Name: Last name
Fact.Description: The last name of the filer. Must match the name as known to the Social Security Administration.

Fact.Name: Full name
Fact.Description: The first name, middle initial, and last name of the filer. Primarily used for the frontend.
The first name, middle initial, and last name of the filer. Abbreviated/truncated to MeF requirements.
The suffix of the filer.

Fact.Name: Suffix string
Fact.Description: The suffix of the filer as a string for concatenation.
The suffix of the filer. Exported for mef

Fact.Name: TIN
Fact.Description: The taxpayer identification number of the filer.

Fact.Name: Date of birth
Fact.Description: The date of birth of the filer.
The day before the filer's birthday

Fact.Name: Age
Fact.Description: The age of the filer, calcualted using their birthday as the day before their date of birth.
Used to set SelfSelectPINGrp.SpouseBirthDt in XML when applicable

Fact.Name: Age
Fact.Description: The age of the filer on the last day of the tax year.

Fact.Name: Age
Fact.Description: The age of the filer with no qualifying children at then end of tax year who requires form 8862 for EITC; for PDF form 8862

Fact.Name: Filer is a student
Fact.Description: Whether the filer is a student.

Fact.Name: Filer is Disabled
Fact.Description: Whether the filer is disabled.
Filer is either a student or disabled
Filer is a student and is not disabled. Used for content conditions.
Filer is disabled and not is not a student. Used for content conditions.
Filer is a student and is disabled. Used for content conditions.
Filer (or spouse if MFJ) is a student and neither is disabled
Filer (or spouse if MFJ) is disabled and neither is a student
Filer (or spouse if MFJ) is a student and filer (or spouse if MFJ) is disabled

Fact.Name: Months disabled or in school
Fact.Description: The number of months the filer was either disabled or in school in the current tax year
Whether the age of the filer is less than 16

Fact.Name: Younger than 16
Fact.Description: Whether either filer is younger than 16.

Fact.Name: Age 65 or older
Fact.Description:
Whether the filer is 65 or older. Pub 554 states "You are considered age 65 at the end of the year if your 65th birthday is on or before January 1 of the following year" so we include the January 1 exception here.
Do NOT use this fact for EITC calculations -- That age 65 requirement does _not_ have the January 1 exception.

Fact.Name: Age 55 or older
Fact.Description: Whether the filer is 55 or older at the end of their tax year.
At least one TP is 65 or older
At least one TP is under 65.

Fact.Name: Age 25 or older
Fact.Description:
Whether the filer is 25 or older for EITC. A person is considered 25 if they turned 25 during the tax year, or on January 1 of the next year.
Per pub 596 for 2022 "You meet the age test if you were born after December 31, 1957, and before January 2, 1998. If you are married filing a joint return, you meet the age test if either you or your spouse was born after December 31, 1957, and before January 2, 1998."
This is explicitly different than the rule for turning 65 (the maximum age for EITC without QCs), which occurs on the person's birthday, not the day after. Because the tax code is silly.

The fact that should be listed as someone's age on Form 8862 for EITC. Uses convoluted logic because the age for the 25 year old minimum age uses the day before the person's birthday, and the age for the 65 year old maximum uses the day of the person's brithday.

Fact.Name: Age 64 or younger
Fact.Description: Whether the filer is 64 or younger for EITC.

Fact.Name: Occupation
Fact.Description: The occupation of the filer.

Fact.Name: Occupation code
Fact.Description: The occupation code of the filer.

Fact.Name: Identity Pin
Fact.Description: The identity pin of the filer

Fact.Name: Spouse Identity Pin
Fact.Description: The identity pin of the spouse. Used in the Return Header XML.

Fact.Name: Filer is blind
Fact.Description: Whether the filer is considered blind for tax purposes.

Fact.Name: Filer has IP Pin
Fact.Description: Whether the filer has been assigned an IP pin from the IRS

Fact.Name: Filer has IP Pin
Fact.Description: Whether the filer is ready to input their IP pin in the flow

Fact.Name: Filer has spouse's IP Pin
Fact.Description: Whether the filer is ready to input their spouse's IP pin in the flow. Currently separated to be able to conjugate the pronoun in the question, but we can eliminate this variable if we improve our translation customization.

Fact.Name: Filer can be claimed as a dependent
Fact.Description: Whether the filer can be claimed as a dependent by another taxpayer.

Fact.Name: Filer can be claimed as a dependent and has no qualifying children
Filer cannot be claimed as a dependent
Fact.Description: Whether the filer cannot be claimed as a dependent by another taxpayer and has no qualifying children; used for pdf form 8862

Fact.Name: Person who could claim filer as dependent must file
Fact.Description: Whether the person who could claim the filer as a dependent is required to file a tax return.

Fact.Name: Person who could claim filer as dependent filed
Fact.Description: Whether the person who could claim the filer as a dependent filed a tax return.

Fact.Name: Person who could claim the primary filer as dependent filed solely for refund
Fact.Description: Whether the person who could claim the primary filer as a dependent filed a tax return solely for refund of withholding or estimated tax paid.

Fact.Name: Filer expects to be claimed as a dependent
Fact.Description: Whether the filer expects to be claimed as a dependent by another taxpayer. Note that this fact should not be used directly, as it can be overwridden if we later learn no one else is allowed to claim the taxpayer; use /primaryFilerIsClaimedAsDependent or /secondaryFilerIsClaimedAsDependent instead.

Fact.Name: Filer is claimed as a dependent
Fact.Description: Whether the filer is claimed as a dependent by another taxpayer.

Fact.Name: Secondary filer is claimed as a dependent
Fact.Description: Whether the secondary filer is claimed as a dependent by another taxpayer. False if not MFJ.

Fact.Name: A filer on the return is claimed as a dependent
Fact.Description: Either the primary or secondary filer is claimed as a dependent by another taxpayer.
Whether the MFJ filer who can be someone's dependent is claiming a refund only and forgoing tax benefits like dependents and certain credits
Whether the MFJ filer is claiming a refund only and neither primary nor secondary can be claimed as a dependent
Whether the MFJ filer is claiming a refund only and forgoing tax benefits like dependents and certain credits

Fact.Name: Taxpayer could be a dependent
Fact.Description: Whether the primary TP could be a dependent. If they are not MFJ, then they in fact are a dependent. The only way for them not to be a dependent is if they file as MFJ and are required to file, or if they file as MFJ and opt to claim tax benefits.
If the primary filer has restrictions on their social security number, we know them
If the secondary filer has restrictions on their social security number, we know they completed answering questions about them.
The About You section is complete

Fact.Name: Fact for controlling the flow of showing the MFJ Spouse Filing Requirement Subsection
Fact.Description: Either the secondary filer can be claimed or the secondary filer can not be claimed and the primary filer is claimed.

The filer can be claimed as a dependent by someone who must file, or by someone who is filing for credits + deductions (not just for a refund). This means that they themselves cannot claim dependents, or use qualifying children to claim EITC. If they are filing MFJ, the filers have to choose to file for refund only to get into this status.
This means that we treat the filers as dependents, and in this case: 1. They will not be eligible to claim dependents, CTC, or ODC 2. They will receive a reduced standard deduction.

Fact.Name: MFJ Required to File
Fact.Description: Whether an MFJ couple is required to file
Whether either filer can be claimed

Fact.Name: isMFJDependent
Fact.Description: Whether the TP is categorized as an MFJ dependent

Fact.Name: Taxpayer cannot be claimed
Fact.Description: The taxpayer is filing a joint return for tax benefits and cannot be claimed by another taxpayer

Fact.Name: Filer is primary
Fact.Description: The primary filer is listed first on the tax return.

Fact.Name: Filer is secondary
Fact.Description: The secondary filer is listed second on the tax return.

Fact.Name: Secondary filer for use in generating PDFs
Fact.Description: The spouse, if they should appear in PDFs as the secondary filer

Fact.Name: Employment validity for the primary filer
Fact.Description: Employment validity statements printed on filer's Social Security card.

Fact.Name: Employment validity
Fact.Description: Employment validity statements printed on filer's Social Security card.
The SSN is marked "not valid" for employment
Does the filer only have a SSN to apply for federal benefits
Does the filer only have a SSN to apply for federal benefits

Fact.Name: Citizenship
Fact.Description: Whether the filer was a U.S. Citizen for all of the tax year

Fact.Name: Needs SSN Work Status
Fact.Description: A test for whether the flow should ask if the filer's SSN card has printed work-validitiy info

Fact.Name: (Writable) Citizenship at end of tax year
Fact.Description: (Writable) Whether the filer was a U.S. Citizen at the end of the tax year after starting the year as a U.S. resident

Fact.Name: Citizenship at end of tax year
Fact.Description: Whether the filer was a U.S. Citizen at the end of the tax year after starting the year as a U.S. resident

Fact.Name: (Writable) Non-citizen residency (full tax year)
Fact.Description: (Writable) Was the filer a resident for the whole tax year and not a citizen?

Fact.Name: Non-citizen residency (full tax year)
Fact.Description: Was the filer a resident for the whole tax year and not a citizen? Includes spouses who are non-residents but whom have elected to be treated as a resident for tax purposes per IRC 6013(g), Election to Treat Nonresident Individual as Resident of the United States

Fact.Name: (Writable) U.S. National
Fact.Description: (Writable) Whether the filer was a U.S. national

Fact.Name: U.S. National
Fact.Description: Whether the filer was a U.S. national
Was the filer a citizen all year, by the end of the year, or a national

Fact.Name: Primary filer because citizen and residency status
Fact.Description: Whether the primary filer was knocked out due to their citizen and residency status

Fact.Name: Number of days lived in the United States
Fact.Description: The number of days the filer's main home was in the U.S. Used for pdf form 8862. Assumed to be 365 because taxpayers assert that they live in the state where their income was sourced all year

Fact.Name: Income from supported state
Fact.Description: Which state(s) the filer earned income in from our in-scope states

Fact.Name: Primary filer's W-2 and 1099-INT forms are from an in-scope state
Fact.Description: Did all of the primary filer's W-2 and 1099-INT forms come from the same in-scope state?
Did the primary filer have an Alaska Permanent Fund Dividend?
Did the secondary filer have an Alaska Permanent Fund Dividend?

Fact.Name: Spouse's W-2 and 1099-INT forms are from an in-scope state
Fact.Description: Did all of the spouse's W-2 and 1099-INT forms come from the same in-scope state?

The filer lives in a Community Property state, where the income of a married couple is considered shared property of both individuals. This does not include two states, Tennessee and South Dakota, which have elective Community Property laws.

Fact.Name: All primary filer income forms are from an in-scope state
Fact.Description: Derives a state based on all primary filer income forms, prioritizing 'anotherState'.

Fact.Name: All spouse income forms are from an in-scope state
Fact.Description: Derives a state based on all spouse income forms, prioritizing 'anotherState'.
The filer has some W-2 forms from out of state

Fact.Name: The filer(s) lives in New York
Fact.Description: We support a special set of Box 14 codes for New York, so we need to condition the flow on whether the filer(s) lived there in the tax year

Fact.Name: The filer(s) lives in New Jersey
Fact.Description: We support a special set of Box 14 codes for New Jersey, so we need to condition the flow on whether the filer(s) lived there in the tax year

Fact.Name: The filer(s) lives in Maryland
Fact.Description: We support a special set of Box 14 codes for Maryland, so we need to condition the flow on whether the filer(s) lived there in the tax year

Fact.Name: The filer(s) lives in North Carolina
Fact.Description: We show North Carolina-specific information when the filer(s) lives in North Carolina

Fact.Name: The filer(s) lives in Massachusetts
Fact.Description: Washington has a Working Families Tax Credit, so we need a condition to show Massachusetts-specific content.

Fact.Name: The filer(s) lives in Washington State
Fact.Description: Washington has a Working Families Tax Credit, so we need a condition to send the filer(s) to the website in order to check their eligibility.

Fact.Name: The filer(s) lives in California
Fact.Description: California does not support transferring data from Direct File, so we need a condition so that we can provide relavent content to the filer(s) living there.
Lived in Alaska
Lived in Hawaii
Filing deadline based on the TP's state of residence

Fact.Name: Filer(s) may benefit from filing state taxes
Fact.Description: Used to show additional info on knockout screen that filer(s) may benefit from filing state taxes
The primary filer earned income either in none of our in scope states or multiple

Fact.Name: Resident of specific states
Fact.Description: Whether the filer resides in CA, CO, CT, DC, GA, ID, KY, ME, MD, MA, MN, NV, NJ, NM, NY, PA, RI, VT and WA.

Fact.Name: State Marketplace Name
Fact.Description: Returns the marketplace name key for states with their own health insurance marketplace
The spouse earned income either in none of our in scope states or multiple
The primary filer earned income or W-2 forms either in none of our in scope states or multiple

Fact.Name: Flow: Filer Has Income In-Scope
Fact.Description: The filer has only earned income in ONE of our in-scope states

Fact.Name: The state(s) in which the taxpayer should file state taxes
Fact.Description: The sole fact used to determine where the taxpayer should file state taxes

Fact.Name: Primary filer
Fact.Description: The primary filer of the tax return.

Fact.Name: Secondary filer
Fact.Description: The secondary filer of the tax return, if there is one.

Fact.Name: Primary filer can be claimed as a dependent
Fact.Description: Whether the 1040 should indicate someone can claim primary filer as a dependent.
Not MFJ + /primaryFilerCouldBeDependentAndClaimerIsRequiredToFileOrFilingForCredits

Fact.Name: Secondary filer can be claimed as a dependent
Fact.Description: Whether the 1040 should indicate someone can claim secondary filer as a dependent.

Fact.Name: Filer has TIN
Fact.Description: The filer has provided their TIN

Fact.Name: Filers with TINs
Fact.Description: All filers who have provided TINs

Fact.Name: Filer Tin is unique
Fact.Description: Is this filer's TIN unique among filers with TINs?

Fact.Name: Exempt spouse
Fact.Description: The spouse of the primary filer if the spouse is exempt. Used for populating the 1040's exempt spousal information.

Fact.Name: Is spouse exempt
Fact.Description: Whether the spouse of the primary filer is exempt from filing a separate tax return.

Fact.Name: Date of birth of oldest filer
Fact.Description: The date of birth of the oldest filer, for purposes of the age test for qualifying children.

Fact.Name: Is the filer's spouse itemizing deductions?
Fact.Description: If your spouse itemizes deductions on their tax return when filing separately from you, it means you the filer cannot take the standard deduction on their own return.

Fact.Name: Spouse itemizes knockout
Fact.Description: We should knock the user out because their spouse is filing and itemizing. Includes both facts to be defensive to edits.

Fact.Name: 64 Years before tax year
Fact.Description: 64 years before the current tax year.
The date of death of the secondary filer.
The date of death of the primary filer's spouse. Used to populate the form 1040 SpouseDeathDt XML element.
Whether the primary filer has a deceased spouse currently supported by DF. Used to populate the form 1040 SurvivingSpouseInd element.
The age that the spouse may have turned during the year they died

The age at death of the filer when counting the day before their birthday as their birthday. This birthday definition is used for at least the standard deduction and the 25-year minimum age for EITC. It is not used for the 65 year maximum age for EITC.

The age of the secondary filer on their date of death, counting their actual date of birth as their birthday. This is used for the 65-year maximum age on self-only EITC, but is not used for the 25-year minimum age, or for standard deduction.

Fact.Name: Whether the deceased spouse turned age 65 in the tax year.
Fact.Description: The spouse died and turned 65 in the tax year. Calculated using their day of birth as the day before their birthday. Cannot be used for the EIC calculation.

Fact.Name: **SUPERCEDES /MFSSpouseFilingReturn.** Whether or not the spouse is filing a return.
Fact.Description: If the spouse is filing a return or having a return filed for them. I'm intentionally leaving this as all marital statuses except widowed here though i could be convinced to add a case for married only. Tests in filers.test.ts reflect this choice. kate3/6/24

Fact.Name: **DEPRECATED: The correct fact to rely on is now /MFSSpouseFilingReturnDerived.** MFS spouse will file return
Fact.Description: If the spouse is filing a return or having a return filed for them.

Fact.Name: Living MFS spouse will file return
Fact.Description: Active voice: "my MFS spouse will file a return"

Fact.Name: Dead MFS spouse will have return filed for them
Fact.Description: Passive voice: "someone will file a return for my MFS spouse"

Fact.Name: Wether or not the spouse has a Tax Identification Number
Fact.Description: If the spouse has a Tax Identification Number

Fact.Name: Whether or not the spouse has a gross income.
Fact.Description: If the spouse had any gross income in the tax year.

Fact.Name: Whether or not the spouse is 65 or older.
Fact.Description: If the spouse had reached age 65 in the tax year.

Fact.Name: Whether to get the taxID of the spouse.
Fact.Description: Check if the spouse has a NRTIN or is a US citizen.

Fact.Name: Whether MFS TP lives in NC or MD and spouse has no TIN/SSN.
Fact.Description: Check if the MFS TP lives in NC or MD and spouse has no TIN/SSN.

Fact.Name: The MFS spouse will provide no benefits for the standard deduction.
Fact.Description: End the questionaire if the spouse is filing a tax return or does have gross income or can be claimed as a dependent.

Fact.Name: Married Filing Separately Threshold Amount
Fact.Description: Filing threshold amount for filers who are married filing separately. (Equal to the amount of the personal exemption, but due to suspension of the personal exemption under TCJA, the exemption was reduced to $0. While the exemption is $0, IRS will use $5 as the threshold.)

Fact.Name: Filers's marriage is valid for MFJ
Fact.Description: The filer's spouse met some citizenship or residency requirement that allows them to file jointly. https://www.irs.gov/publications/p519

Fact.Name: Filer's W-2 and 1099-G forms are from an in-scope state
Fact.Description: Did all of the filer's W-2 and 1099-G forms come from the same state?

Fact.Name: Whether spouse lives in the tax payer's state
Fact.Description: Whether the filer's spouse lived in the same state as them all year, in mulitple states, or something else
Spouse questions related to living together/apart have been completed

Fact.Name: Lived with the spouse during the entire tax year
Fact.Description: Whether the taxpayer lived together with their spouse the entire Tax Year

Fact.Name: Months lived apart from spouse during tax year
Fact.Description: Months lived apart from their spouse in the Tax Year

Fact.Name: Months Spouse Lived Apart Options
Fact.Description: Months a spouse lived apart options
Whether the taxpayer lived with their spouse for six months or less.
Whether the taxpayer lived with their spouse for more than six months but less than the full year.
Whether to show the separation agreement screen based on the taxpayer living with their spouse for more than six months but not the whole year.
Whether the taxpayer lived apart from their spouse for the last six months of the year.
Whether the taxpayer lived apart from their spouse for the last six months of the year. Takes into account implied answers based on previous information.

Fact.Name: Lived apart from spouse the whole year
Fact.Description: Whether the taxpayer lived apart from their spouse for the whole year.

Fact.Name: Spouse separation agreement last day
Fact.Description: Whether the taxpayer was living apart from their spouse and had a separation agreement on the last day of the year.

Fact.Name: Spouse separation agreement last day
Fact.Description: Whether the taxpayer was living apart from their spouse and had a separation agreement on the last day of the year.

Fact.Name: Qualified to file jointly in year of spouse death
Fact.Description: Whether the taxpayer was qualified to file jointly for the year in which their spouse died.

Fact.Name: Marital Status Options
Fact.Description: Options for a marital status

Fact.Name: Marital status
Fact.Description: The marital status the primary filer tells us.

Fact.Name: The filer declared they are married
Fact.Description: The filer stated they are married

Fact.Name: Single
Fact.Description: The filer stated they were never married.

Fact.Name: Widowed
Fact.Description: The primary filer's marital status is widowed.

Fact.Name: Is (really Was) Widowed in Tax Year
Fact.Description: Was the filer widowed in the current tax year?

Fact.Name: Widowed before tax year minus two
Fact.Description: The TP was widowed before TY minus 2

Fact.Name: Check For Registered Domestic Partner
Fact.Description: Whether to show the filer the question to see if they had a registered domestic partner. Only show the question if they chose "never married", "widowed", "divorced or legally separated" and if they live in a Community Property state (this is overly broad, but avoids us needing to produce an exhaustive list of county and local registries).

Fact.Name: In Registered Domestic Partnership
Fact.Description: Whether the filer was in a registered domestic partnership in the tax year or not.

Fact.Name: Has completed registered domestic partner if applicable
Fact.Description: Checks whether registered domestic partnership is applicable and if so ensures it's complete

Fact.Name: Flow knockout for registered domestic partnership
Fact.Description: Registered domestic partnership is applicable and user has one

The filer is subject to community property laws if they are only eligible for MFS, or they chose MFS, or they chose HoH and said their marital status is married and they live in Arizona, California, Nevada, Texas, or Washinton.

Fact.Name: Filers couldn't be dependents
Fact.Description: Neither filer could be claimed as a dependent.

Fact.Name: Year of Spouse Death Options
Fact.Description: The year that a taxpayer's spouse died

Fact.Name: Year of spouse's death
Fact.Description: The relative year a widowed filer's spouse died.

Fact.Name: Either filer not in a supported state
Fact.Description: Used to control a flow knockout state

Fact.Name: Address
Fact.Description: The mailing address of the taxpayer(s).
The combination of street address lines 1 and 2

Fact.Name: Mailing address zip in MeF Format
Fact.Description: The mailing address zip of the taxpayer(s), with hyphens and spaces stripped for MeF compliance

Fact.Name: US State Name
Fact.Description: The state inside the US if the address isn't foreign

Fact.Name: Foreign State Name
Fact.Description: The state/provence outside the US

Fact.Name: Foreign Country Name
Fact.Description: The country outside the US

Fact.Name: US Postal Code
Fact.Description: The postal code if the address is in the US

Fact.Name: Foreign Postal Code
Fact.Description: The postal code when the address is not in the US

Fact.Name: Phone
Fact.Description: The phone number of the taxpayer(s).

Fact.Name: Email address
Fact.Description: The email address of the taxpayer(s).
The string version of the email

The email address of the taxpayer(s) sent to MeF. If the address is over 75 characters, we do not send an email. This is allowed by MeF Business rules, and they will not accept emails over 75 characters in length

Fact.Name: Whether, prior to asking about dependents, the TP might be eligible for HoH
Fact.Description: Whether, prior to asking about dependents, the TP might qualify as HoH. Used to decide whether to ask the questions about whether a person could be a dependent. A TP is eligible for be HoH as long as they are not eligible to file MFJ. If they are married, they need to have lived apart for the last six months or the spouse must have been a noncitizen who was not a resident for the fully TY.
Based on filer information, the filer may qualify for QSS
Based on filer + spouse information, the filer may qualify for EITC

Based on filer + spouse information only, the filer could qualify to receive CDCC Credit for any qualifying people. If MFJ, they could all qualify, but if MFS, they can't unless they are considered unmarried. At this point we cannot determine mfsConsideredUnmarried completely as we don't know information per qualifying person.

Based on filer + spouse only - whether the MFS primary filer could be considered unmarried for purposes of claiming the credit on Form 2441. This does not include the per-qualifying-person requirements.
Whether the TP(s) have a valid SSN for EITC

Fact.Name: Filer(s) are US citizen or RA all year
Fact.Description: Whether the TP(s) are U.S. citizens or resident aliens all year

Fact.Name: Primary filer is citizen or RA all year
Fact.Description: Whether the primary filer is a U.S. citizen or resident alien the entire year

Fact.Name: Secondary filer is citizen or RA all year
Fact.Description: Whether the secondary filer is a U.S. citizen or resident alien the entire year

Fact.Name: Either filer is a US citizen or US national
Fact.Description: Whether at least one of the TPs is a U.S. citizen or U.S. national
Both filers (when applicable) are U.S. citizens or U.S. nationals

Fact.Name: Primary filer is a U.S. citizen or U.S. national
Fact.Description: Whether the primary filer is a U.S. citizen or U.S. national

Fact.Name: Secondary filer is a U.S. citizen or U.S. national
Fact.Description: Whether the secondary filer is a U.S. citizen or U.S. national

Fact.Name: Special rule for separated spouses
Fact.Description: Checks whether the spouse lived apart the last 6 months or are legally separated
The filer(s) are eligible to enter people. This means that they are still potentially eligible to claim deductions, credits, or HoH/QSS filing status.

Fact.Name: Is the secondary filer a non-resident alien
Fact.Description: Whether the secondaryFiler is considered a non-resident alien.

Fact.Name: NRA literal code
Fact.Description: The code used to populate the IRS 1040 NRALiteralCd (nonresident alien) XML element when required

Fact.Name: The spouse's name
Fact.Description: The spouse's name used to populate the SpouseNm 1040 XML element.

Fact.Name: Conditional spouse name
Fact.Description: A spouse name that will be blank if the filer is not married. Helpful because we don't clear /secondaryFiler/fullName if the filer changes their marital status

Fact.Name: 1040SR Indicator
Fact.Description: Whether these filer(s) should be filing on a 1040SR

Fact.Name: Negate 1040SR Indicator
Fact.Description: Whether these filer(s) should be filing on a regular 1040

Fact.Name: Primary filer is MFS and is considered unmarried for the purposes of claiming CDCC credit
Fact.Description: The TP is considered unmarried for the purposes of claiming CDCC credit. At this point we should be able to fully determine whether they are eligible for the credit. Used to set `EligibilityRequirementMetInd` in MeF. Form 2441, Line A

Fact.Name: Primary filer is MFS and is considered married
Fact.Description: If the filer meets some requirements, they are considered unmarried for the purposes of claiming CDCC credit. This filer did not meet those requirements and will be considered married. Used for determining Child and Dependent Care Credit.
Whether the filer is under 18 for purposes of the Saver's Credit
Whether the filer is eligible for the saver's credit based on filer info
Whether the filer is the primary filer or MFJ and either primary or secondary.
This filer qualifies the taxpayer for CDCC
Filers who qualify the taxpayer for CDCC
We have collected expenses for CDCC if required. Used to test completion of the CDCC QP loop.

Fact.Name: Qualifying Expense Amount for CDCC
Fact.Description: Amount of qualifying expenses paid for this qualifying person. Only applies if the person is a CDCC QP and a filer

Fact.Name: Qualifying Expense Amount for CDCC
Fact.Description: Amount of qualifying expenses paid for this qualifying person. Only applies if the person is a CDCC QP and a filer
Whether the QP has qualifying dependent care expenses
Whether the QP's expenses were paid to a qualified provider
Whether this filer who was a qp for cdcc had expenses that were qualifying and paid to a qualified provider

Fact.Name: Filer has 1095-A in IRDAS
Fact.Description: Whether the filer has at least one Form 1095-A in IRDAS
